node.title: Using X,Y,Z,Variable csv data to define elemental variables using PiecewiseConstantFromCSV
node.bodyText: I have a csv file of a value (T) as a function of x,y,z in a csv file, and was hoping to use the new PiecewiseConstantFromCSV to read that in such that each element is assigned an elemental value of T from the closest point defined in the csv file. At the moment this is working, except that it is assigning the variable to nodes instead of elements. Is there anyway to force an elemental value while using the nearest style reader?

Never-mind, figured it out. By making the variable an auxiliary variable and setting order = constant and family = monomial you can enforce elemental values from a nearest neighbour/voronoi reader. Not sure this is the best method available but it seems to work for me.

hello
yes that's the way
Cool, thanks for the confirmation.

node.title: Custom material to compute thermal expansion with a variable thermal expansion coefficient.

node.bodyText:
For the second time today I've figured out my problem not long after asking for help, I now have this working.
The issue was on the line:
 _thermal_expansion_coeff(this->template declareGenericProperty<Real, is_ad>(getParam<MaterialPropertyName>("thermal_expansion_coeff")))
I had based this on code from CoupledValueFunctionMaterial, specifically the line:
_prop(declareGenericProperty<Real, is_ad>(getParam<MaterialPropertyName>("prop_name")))
By instead copying from ComputeEigenstrain:
_prefactor(this->template getGenericMaterialProperty<Real, is_ad>("prefactor"))
And changing the line to:
_thermal_expansion_coeff(this->template getGenericMaterialProperty<Real, is_ad>("thermal_expansion_coeff"))
it is working.

node.title: Parsed Material for tensor properties
node.bodyText:
Hi,
my application requires something like ParsedMaterial but to initialize a tensor from arguments and other material properties (each component individually). I could not find such functionality in the code, but since this is maybe a common problem someone has already coded this up? Or I overlooked something?
Cheers

@dschwen have you heard of a ParsedTensorMaterial out there?
Guillaume
That sounds like exactly what I need :)

Hi @GiudGiud ,
A regular tensor material would not have the dependencies on arguments of each component, right?
I've found a workaround for my usecase by adding different tensors together, with variable-dependent weights, aka. CompositeTensor.
But a ParsedTensorMaterial would be a nice functionality and still useful to me.

hello
Well you can definitely create a new object in the source code and have any dependencies you want. I guess it's not clear what I meant by "regular"
I ll see if i can create one in the near future, I ll let you know here if I have time
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume,
I was thinking of writing it up, but I didn't find the time as well. It would also take me some time to understand and design how to interface with ParsedFunctions etc... (fairly new to MOOSE). And the workaround with the CompositeTensor is sufficient for my usecase, but not elegant. For newbie-users however, I think it would be a nice functionality.

node.title: Oscillations in INS velocity field
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I am using the FE implementation of the Navier Stokes module with two phase flows, using the Level Set method for interface tracking. I am having some issues with oscillations in the vertical component of the velocity field, see image below. The scenario for this test is just steady state with a less dense fluid sat above a denser fluid. All boundaries except the top are no-penetration (so v dot n = 0 on the boundaries of the mesh) and the pressure on the top boundary is fixed to zero (it also displays the same behaviour without applying it). I am using first order elements for all variables and running with PSPG and SUPG. This scenario is just testing that it produces a stable result, I would expect the velocities to tend to zero but instead these variations are observed and over time their magnitude increases until it will no longer solve.
Am I missing something obvious?
Thanks,
Alex
@lindsayad who can we tag on level set?
@aeslaughter 😄 I don't think any of our current team members have done much development in that module
@ABallisat how do things look if you make the two phases the same? (densities, etc.)

Same densities work to what I take is numerical error:

In the original post, the densities ratio was O(1:1000), I also tried O(1:4) (not shown) which also displays similar oscillatory behaviour so I guess it comes down to the densities. Based on that, is the FE INS implementation designed to work with variable density?

Both convection and time derivative terms (in MOOSE's INS kernels in navier_stokes) assume that the density can be pulled outside the differential operator (d/dt and div respectively) which reflects an assumption of constant density.
Are you creating your own level set kernels, or are you using the level_set module?

I've had a good dig through the literature and there is a mix of formulations, some authors claim to use pulling out the density of the differential operators whilst others include them. At the moment I have not written kernels with them included in the differential operators but I think it would be sensible to see if this has an effect so I will attempt to implement this.
As for level set, I have been using the level_set module for propagation but given the reinitialisation implementation seems to not work at times, I have implemented a parallel fast marching implementation to do that bit.
@ABallisat any update on this?

Apologies for just getting around to replying, I have been busy on other things recently. Long story short no, I had a good go at it but could never get it to converge. For now I have switched my attention to the finite volume implementation and seeing if that is any more suited to it. I played around with finite volume a long while ago but hit the caching problem so the memory usage was too high and it did not scale up. I have seen that that has now been fixed so will be interesting to see how much that has improved. I will report back on how I get on.

Sounds good.
Closing this for now.
We'd be interested in an implementation of phase field in finite volume if you can do the conversion.
Do we have a final conclusion on whether different densities are supported?

I said that the INS FE implementation assumes that density is constant such that you can pull it out of derivative terms, so any spatial or temporal derivatives related to density would have to be added by the user if they wanted to also use the INS FE kernels.
That being said, density in INS FE is a material property, so you could in theory "use" the INS FE objects with a non-constant density. It's just that omission of the additional derivative terms related to density would lead to an incorrect representation of the NS physics

node.title: 1d Spring Dampers
node.bodyText: Hi all, simple question here. I've done a bit of digging through the source docs and have struggled to find a simple way of implementing 1D spring dampers in a model. Is there no simple inbuilt tool for this purpose? Just checking there isn't before I make one myself.
@jiangwen84 @gambka any hints on this?

This is as a simplification of a physical component in a structure. I suppose they'd be attached to displacements and velocities between nodes. I'm suspecting that this could actually be achieved by the tactical application of DynamicTensorMechanics to 1D mesh elements.

not sure.
This seems like an ODE that would live on a single node to me. PLease have a look at the NodalKernel system and let me know if it seems like the way to do this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/NodalKernels/index.html

node.title: Is the function to calculate 'EffectiveStrain' in 'RankTwoScalarTools' invalid now?
node.bodyText:
According to https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/utils/RankTwoScalarTools.html , the effective plastic strain or effective creep strain could be obtained by using the ' effectiveStrain' method.

But acturally in MOOSE:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/25abc3b0f580842db2924dcdb643bbf4b99406d1/modules/tensor_mechanics/include/utils/RankTwoScalarTools.h ,
the option of  ' effectiveStrain'  corresponds to a 'mooseError'.
The error message is accurate, which is also consistent with the documentation.
Does that means  if we want to get the effective plastic strain or effective creep strain，other method should be adopted or we would get an error ?

yes you want to be using the new API that the error code is mentioning.
Can you not update to use that one?
yes i can create a new 'Auxkernel' and use "RankTwoScalarTools::effectiveStrain()" to get the effective strain. Thanks for your reply @hugary1995  @GiudGiud

node.title: the use of displaced mesh
node.bodyText:
I want to implement the displaced mesh configuration by using the "displacement='disp_x disp_y'" and "_use_displaced_mesh=true" . The mesh can now be seen moving over time on the console, but the solve show the same results as if the displacement field had not been applied. I suspect that the coordinate values do not change at each step, resulting in results that are not related to the moving mesh. Is there any way that the coordinate values can be changed at each step to affect the calculation of the equations.
#[GlobalParams]
  #order = FIRST
  #family = LAGRANGE
  #disp_x = disp_x
  #disp_y = disp_y
  #displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
#[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  #use_displaced_mesh = true
[]

[Mesh]
  file = grids/test03.exo
  use_displaced_mesh = true
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'

  block_id = 3
  block_name = 'fluid'

  boundary_id = '1 2'
  boundary_name = 'wall far'
  uniform_refine = 1
[]

[Problem]
  type = EulerProblem
  mach = 0.6
  attack = 0
  jacobian_delay = 1
  flux_type = HLL

  [./Kernels]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    type = CFDCellKernel
    shock_indicator = indicator
    block = '3'
  [../]

  [./DGKernels]
    type = CFDFaceKernel
    block = '3'
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '3'
  [../]

  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '3'
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./disp_x_kernel]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = disp_x
    function = 'sqrt(x^2+y^2)*cos(atan(y/x)-4.86/360*2*pi-2.44*sin(0.1620*t)/360*2*pi) - x'
    block = '3'
  [../]

  [./disp_y_kernel]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = disp_y
    function = 'sqrt(x^2+y^2)*sin(atan(y/x)-4.86/360*2*pi-2.44*sin(0.1620*t)/360*2*pi) - y'
    block = '3'
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  variables = 'density momx momy momz rhoe'
[]

[ICs]
  type = CFDPassFlowIC
[]

[BoundaryCondition]
  [./euler_far_field]
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = FarFieldPressure
    boundary = '2'
  [../]

  [./euler_wall]
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = RotarySlipWall
    boundary = '1'
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Adaptivity]
  #marker = marker
  #max_h_level = 2
  [./Indicators]
    [./indicator]
      type =  DensityJumpIndicator
      variable = density
      scale = 0
    [../]
  [../]
  [./Markers]
    [./marker]
      type = ErrorMaxFractionMarker
      indicator = indicator
      coarsen = 0.7
      refine = 0.5
    [../]
  [../]
[]


[Executioner]
  no_fe_reinit = true
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  num_steps = 1000
  l_tol = 5e-02
  l_max_its = 20

  nl_max_its = 20
  nl_rel_tol = 0.999999

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = RatioTimeStepper
    dt = 1E-02
    ratio = 2
    step = 5
    max_dt = 0.5
  [../]
[]

[CFDForce]
  [cfdforce]
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = CFDForceUserObject
    boundary = 'wall'
    ref_point = '0 0 0'
    ref_length = 1
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./residuals]
    type = VariableResidual
    variable = density
  [../]
  [cd]
    type = CFDForcePostprocessor3
    solution = cfdforce
  []
  [cl]
    type = CFDForcePostprocessor2
    solution = cfdforce
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
  checkpoint = true
  #show = 'density momx momy momz rhoe disp_x disp_y'

  [./console]
    type = Console
    perf_log = true
    execute_on = 'linear nonlinear'
  [../]

  [./exodus]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
    interval = 2
  [../]

  #[./tecplot]
    #type = Tecplot
    #execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
    #interval = 10
  #[../]
[]

Hello
I assume that by the cloud you mean the exodus output?
Have you tried to output the displaced mesh? For this you will need an exodus block in Outputs with the use_displaced parameter set to true.
[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    use_displaced = true
  []
[]

Guillaume

Thank you so much. But I have another question. When I use the  "use_displaced_mesh=true" in the [DGKernel] block, I get an error when I run it, but I found an example inputfile shows that this parameter can be used in the block, so what is the reason for this error?

Hello
So you hit a seg fault. You have narrowed the issue down to CFDFaceKernel ?
Which application is that from? I dont see it in the MOOSE documentation.
Guillaume

In my input file, I found that the displacements='disp_x disp_y disp_z' in the [mesh] block and the use_displaced_ mesh=true in the
[DGkernels] block would conflict, and if both sytax were added at the same time, an error would appear on the console, whereas if the true was changed to false, it would work fine.

I found that the reason may be that use displaced mesh is false by default, which causes it not to run after I set it to true in the input
file, and I wonder if there is a way to change this mandatory-like parameter.

ADDGDiffusion works fine with displaced meshes. There is an example here:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/dgkernels/dg_displacement/dg_displacement.i
I recommend you use our debugging workflow here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
to isolate the problem down to a kernel. I suspect the CFDFaceKernel.

thank you...  But I find that ADDGDiffusion inherits from DGKernel, and the CFDFaceKernel what I am using also inherits from DGKernel. In the dg_displacement.i, the ADDGDiffusion have not used the paramete "boundary = " , and in this case it could use the paramete use_displaced_mesh = true . But in my input file. I have to use the paramete boundary =  to run the use_displaced_mesh = true , but this also leads to unreasonable results.

This is a problem with your implementation of this DGKernel.
Please see these instructions for debugging.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html
once you have obtained a backtrace in debug mode for this error we may be able to help you
Do not add boundary = if the kernel is to be executed in the volume

Thank you for your patience. I can run this simulation now. But I still hava some qustions to ask.
I create an application named parakeet to slove CFD problems, and I add my own physics in it. Now I want to use displaced mesh in input file.
In parakeet, The CFDCellKernel inherit Kernel.C. The CFDFaceKernel inherit DGKernel.C. The CFDBC inherit IntegratedBC.C.
I set the displacement field to 0 and then used use_displaced_mesh=true  only in [Kernel], [DGKernel] and [BCs] respectively. The expected results should be same as if I don't add displacement. But  the results are reasonable when I only use it in [kernel], the other two situation are not as expected.
I had tried to annotation code to find the reason. And I found that when the code in the red box was removed in the CFDFaceKernel.CPP and CFDBC.CPP, the results will be reasonable. But the removed code  is only related to the time-marching, which should only affect convergence,  not calculation results.
I have also tried adjusting the convergence exponent to reduce the residuals to a very low level and the results are still unreasonable. So the reason for the unreasonable results is not convergence. Am I overlooking something, is there anything else I need to pay special attention to when using displaced mesh?
CFDFaceKernel.cpp & CFDBC.cpp:

input file:
[Mesh]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  file = grids/test03.exo
[]

[Problem]
  type = EulerProblem
  mach = 0.15

  [./Kernels]
    disp_x = disp_x
    disp_y = disp_y
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = CFDCellKernel
  [../]

  [./DGKernels]
    disp_x = disp_x
    disp_y = disp_y
    #use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = CFDFaceKernel
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./disp_x_kernel]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = disp_x
    function = '0'
  [../]
  [./disp_y_kernel]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = disp_y
    function = '0'
  [../]
[]

[Variables]
  order = CONSTANT
  family = MONOMIAL
  variables = 'density momx momy momz rhoe'
[]

[ICs]
  type = CFDPassFlowIC
[]

[BoundaryCondition]
  [./euler_far_field]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = FarFieldPressure
    boundary = far
  [../]

  [./euler_wall]
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    type = SlipWall
    boundary = wall
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  type = Transient
  solve_type = PJFNK
  scheme = bdf2

  line_search = 'none'
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-20
  start_time = 0.0
  timestep_tolerance = 1e-6

  num_steps = 1000
  l_tol = 1e-10
  l_max_its = 20

  nl_max_its = 20
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10

  dt = 0.01
  end_time = 5.0
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
  checkpoint = true
  [./console]
    type = Console
    perf_log = true
    execute_on = 'linear nonlinear'
  [../]
  [./exodus]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

Honestly not sure.
I would look at tensor_mechanics and examine how they use the displaced variables in their FE solve.
If you can find other examples of DGKernels adapted for the displaced mesh that's also worth taking into consideration.
A 0 displacement should indeed not affect the solve
Thank you very much, I will try.

@xiaojbing any update on this?
Did you find the problem?

node.title: Applying periodic boundary conditions on subdomain restricted variables
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Users,
As the title says, I would like to know if it is possible in MOOSE to apply
periodic boundary conditions on variables that are restricted to a subdomain/block.
Of course the boundaries on which I want to apply the periodic BC will be the
boundaries of the subdomain.
Does anybody have a successful example of this?
I try to explain what I tried:
I have a structured mesh and I divide it into
an "inner_volume" and "outer_volume".
In the inner_volume I use a model with advection,
representing dislocation transport with some variables that are restricted to the inner_volume.
I define the surfaces of the inner_volume using SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator,
it is just a parallelepiped.
I use the "translation" option to define the periodic BC on the subdomain.
The outer_domain has a phenomenological model without transport.
Tensor mechanics kernels are applied everywhere,
while the dislocation variables have their own kernels restricted to inner_volume.
Two different materials calculate the stress in the two domains.
I show the RVE here:

The results I obtain show that my advected quantity in the inner_volume just accumulates at the boundary,
indicating that Periodic BC are not applied and standard Neumann BC hold:

Moreover, the variable does not look periodic, so I think the Periodic BC is just skipped.
I do not get any warning or error though.
I have to mention the model with transport works very well
when I run the simulation with a single domain, with only the transport model.
In that case, I see the periodic boundary conditions applied properly.
Even though the model is complicated, I have tested it for months with periodic BC
on a single domain and I am sure it works well,
the problem only arises when I switch to two domains
and try to apply periodic BC on the subdomain.
I tried other things:

use "auto" periodic BC on the whole domain
define the surfaces in gmsh instead

but in no case I see the periodic BC applied properly on the subdomain
I attach the complete input file here.
Thank you very much in advance.
Nicolò
FullGrain146_to_post.txt

I want to add that I checked carefully in paraview that the surfaces I defined are correct and same for the translation vectors.
Is there any other thing I can try apart from Periodic BC, like some type of constraint or penalty terms between arbitrary nodes in the mesh?
Thank you
Nicolò
This issue can be probably reproduced on a smaller and simpler problem, e.g, 2 elements and each one is a subdomain,  correct?

@jiangwen84
Thank you for your answer, sure I will try to produce a minimal example.
Actually I noticed in the MOOSE tests this one:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/bcs/periodic/periodic_subdomain_restricted_test.i
which seems to do the same, but I need to check if the result is actually correct.
I will keep you updated.
Nicolò
@ngrilli any update on this?

node.title: Error using CHECKPOINT option
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I'm trying to do simulations on a university cluster using the checkpoint moose option and I obtain this error:
Make sure LIBMESH_HAVE_XDR is defined at build time

The XDR interface is not available in this installation

[11] /home/caligari/AVFLOW/moose/scripts/../libmesh/src/utils/xdr_cxx.C, line 147, compiled

PMIX ERROR: UNREACHABLE in file ../../../../../../../src/openmpi-4.0.5/opal/mca/pmix/pmix3x/pmix/src/server/pmix_server.c at line 2193

Is any solution available?
Thank you

Hello
Please see this answer #20479 (reply in thread)
You need to install libtirpc-devel on your cluster.
If you cant do that and need to use checkpoint anyway please see this answer:
#20479 (comment)
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer.
Can you please link me any information about the installation on cluster?
Thank you very much
This is typically installed by your cluster administrator. You should get in touch with your university cluster administrators

Thank you for your answer,
we have just installed the library, but how can we give to lib mesh the path of the library?

Did you install it in a non-standard place?
If you did not, libmesh will just know
Yes, it is in a non-std place as our system does not provide that library. How and where can I set the paths to a non-std place?

We tried using:
export libmesh_optional_INCLUDES=/home/caligari/AVFLOW/libtirpc-1.3.2/bin/include/tirpc
export CPPFLAGS=-I/home/caligari/AVFLOW/libtirpc-1.3.2/bin/include/
but they didn't work. Do you have any suggestions?

@milljm
this is definitely what you need to do, but there may be subtleties

We tried using:
export libmesh_optional_INCLUDES=/home/caligari/AVFLOW/libtirpc-1.3.2/bin/include/tirpc
export CPPFLAGS=-I/home/caligari/AVFLOW/libtirpc-1.3.2/bin/include/
but they didn't work. Do anyone have any suggestions?

Hello
Is this solved?
Or are you happy enough with the binary = false workaround?
Btw you dont want to discard existing CPP_FLAGS so you may want to have:
export CPPFLAGS=$CPPFLAGS -I/home/caligari/AVFLOW/libtirpc-1.3.2/bin/include/
Guillaume

node.title: Installation issue in Jetstream2 supercomputer
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I installed the MOOSE on the Rocky Linux 8. But when I wanted to run the tests, I got the attached error.
output.txt
Could you please help me with this?
Thanks,
Amir

Hi Amir
The error messages say Application not found so the executable did not build. Could you please report the log of the make command?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your reply. I have attached the log of the 'make' command.
Moose_test.txt
my_test.txt
Thanks,
Amir
Ok now you are getting linking errors with Gffortran. Which platform is this on?
I am using XSEDE Cloud computing. For running jobs parallelly, I need to run the jobs over the Slurm. So I made an instance based on Rocky8, but I cannot install MOOSE correctly.

what does this return:
echo $FC $CC $CXX
which mpicc; which mpif90
mpicc --version

Here is the output. Thanks,
Amir
result.txt

hello
Did you do this?

==> For changes to take effect, close and re-open your current shell. <==

Added mamba to /home/rocky/.bashrc

==> For changes to take effect, close and re-open your current shell. <==

You need to abide by what mambda tells you.
Also, jetstream being a supercomputer as you mentioned, the mamba installation is very unoptimized for it. You should install this way instead:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
Guillaume

Here is the output when I followed up on the mamba orders.
terminal_text.txt
I already installed Moose on another supercomputer by Anaconda and it works well.
Also, I made another instance and I tried to use the Moose installation for HPC Cluster. Here is the error message while we have python on our system.
HPC cluster.txt
Thanks,
Amir

Hey @Amir1361
I can see the error as
python: command not found. I was also having the same issue while installing MOOSE on XSEDE cluster. It has python3 command instead of python. I don't know why.
But, the solution is that you should make .moose_profile bash file and add following text in it
PATH=$PATH:$HOME/bin
export PATH
module load gcc python cmake

and source the file.
Every time you need to run, you should compile the .moose_profile bash file or add those lines in the main .bash file.
Best
Avtar

@GiudGiud Thank you! I am still get error by running the tests in the Moose by Conda:
Moose_Conda.txt
Thank you @asingh-mit. I put them in the Moose Profile:
Moose profile.txt
But again I got the same error:
HPC cluster.txt
Thank you!

Would an alias work for setting python ?
alias python=python3
It does not work. Again I have the python error.

Put the following in .moose_profile
PATH=$PATH:$HOME/bin
export PATH
module load gcc python cmake
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90
export F77=mpif77
export FC=mpif90

save the file.
Then
source .moose_profile
then try to install
After source the file, try to run the command python and see if the cluster is recognizing it.

Cluster recognizes python now. But I get the same error again.
HPC cluster.txt
hello is this still an issue?

Hi,
It was solved. Thanks!
